questions.question_text_1: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?if None: print("None is True") elif 0: print("0 is True") elif "": print("Empty string is True") else: print("All False")
question_texts: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?if None: print("None is True") elif 0: print("0 is True") elif "": print("Empty string is True") else: print("All False")

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below code snippet.def updated_val(d, key, val): if key in d: d[key] += val else: d[key] = val return d[key] my_dict = {'a': 2, 'b': 3} print( updated_val(my_dict, 'c', 4) + updated_val(my_dict, 'c', 2) + updated_val(my_dict, 'a', 2) ) What will be the output of the above code
question_texts: Consider the below code snippet.def updated_val(d, key, val): if key in d: d[key] += val else: d[key] = val return d[key] my_dict = {'a': 2, 'b': 3} print( updated_val(my_dict, 'c', 4) + updated_val(my_dict, 'c', 2) + updated_val(my_dict, 'a', 2) ) What will be the output of the above code

questions.question_text_1: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?def update_records(records, updates): for key, value in updates.items(): if key in records and isinstance(records[key], dict): for sub_key, sub_val in value.items(): if sub_key in records[key]: records[key][sub_key] += sub_val else: records[key][sub_key] = sub_val else: records[key] = value return records data = { "A": {"x": 10, "y": 20}, "B": {"x": 5, "z": 15}, "C": 100 } updates = { "A": {"x": 5, "z": 5}, "B": {"y": 10}, "C": {"x": 10}, "D": {"w": 7} } result = update_records(data, updates) print(result)
question_texts: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?def update_records(records, updates): for key, value in updates.items(): if key in records and isinstance(records[key], dict): for sub_key, sub_val in value.items(): if sub_key in records[key]: records[key][sub_key] += sub_val else: records[key][sub_key] = sub_val else: records[key] = value return records data = { "A": {"x": 10, "y": 20}, "B": {"x": 5, "z": 15}, "C": 100 } updates = { "A": {"x": 5, "z": 5}, "B": {"y": 10}, "C": {"x": 10}, "D": {"w": 7} } result = update_records(data, updates) print(result)

questions.question_text_1: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?def get_square(items, i): return items[i]**2 def safe_get_square(items,i): try: return get_square(items,i) except IndexError: return 0 except: return -1 nums = [5, -2, 3] print(safe_get_square(nums , 1)) print(safe_get_square(nums , -1)) print(safe_get_square([] , -1)) print(safe_get_square(None , 1))
question_texts: Given the following code snippet, what will be the output?def get_square(items, i): return items[i]**2 def safe_get_square(items,i): try: return get_square(items,i) except IndexError: return 0 except: return -1 nums = [5, -2, 3] print(safe_get_square(nums , 1)) print(safe_get_square(nums , -1)) print(safe_get_square([] , -1)) print(safe_get_square(None , 1))

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following snippet of code:filename = "test.txt" with open(filename, "w") as f: f.write("\n".join((f"Line{i}" for i in range(1,11)))) with open(filename, "r") as f: f.readline() f.readline() print(f.read(5)) f.readline() print(f.read(10)) f.seek(0) print(f.read(5)) f.readline() f.readline() print(f.read(5)) Select all that apply.NoteIf a value is passed to f.read , it reads that many number of characters from the current position of the file pointer.•The f.seek method moves the position of the file pointer to the given number of chars after the start of the file.•

questions.question_text_1: Consider the following snippet of code:class Shape: def __init__(self): pass def area(self): return "Area not defined" def describe(self): return f"I am a shape. Area: {self.area()}" class Rectangle(Shape): def __init__(self, width, height): self.width = width self.height = height def area(self): return self.width * self.height class Circle(Shape): def __init__(self, radius): self.radius = radius r = Rectangle(4, 5) c = Circle(3) print(r.describe()) print(c.describe()) What will be the output?
question_texts: Consider the following snippet of code:class Shape: def __init__(self): pass def area(self): return "Area not defined" def describe(self): return f"I am a shape. Area: {self.area()}" class Rectangle(Shape): def __init__(self, width, height): self.width = width self.height = height def area(self): return self.width * self.height class Circle(Shape): def __init__(self, radius): self.radius = radius r = Rectangle(4, 5) c = Circle(3) print(r.describe()) print(c.describe()) What will be the output?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below python code.def process_array(arr): total = 0 for i, row in enumerate(arr): total += row[i] return total array = [] for i in range(5): row = [] for j in range(i + 1): row.append((i + 1) * (j + 1)) array.append(row) print(process_array(array)) What will be the output of the given code?
question_texts: Consider the below python code.def process_array(arr): total = 0 for i, row in enumerate(arr): total += row[i] return total array = [] for i in range(5): row = [] for j in range(i + 1): row.append((i + 1) * (j + 1)) array.append(row) print(process_array(array)) What will be the output of the given code?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below python code.def procedure(child_dict, i): if i not in child_dict.keys(): return 1 ans = 1 for j in child_dict[i]: ans += procedure(child_dict, j) return ans child_dict = dict() child_dict[0] = [1,2] child_dict[1] = [3,4,5] child_dict[2] = [6,7,8] print(procedure(child_dict,0)) What will be the output of the given code?
question_texts: Consider the below python code.def procedure(child_dict, i): if i not in child_dict.keys(): return 1 ans = 1 for j in child_dict[i]: ans += procedure(child_dict, j) return ans child_dict = dict() child_dict[0] = [1,2] child_dict[1] = [3,4,5] child_dict[2] = [6,7,8] print(procedure(child_dict,0)) What will be the output of the given code?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below python code.class A: def __init__(self): self.value = 5 def add(self, num): self.value += num return self.value class B(A): def __init__(self): super().__init__() self.value *= 2 def add(self, num): return super().add(num * 2) obj = B() result = obj.add(3) print(result) What will be the output of the given code?
question_texts: Consider the below python code.class A: def __init__(self): self.value = 5 def add(self, num): self.value += num return self.value class B(A): def __init__(self): super().__init__() self.value *= 2 def add(self, num): return super().add(num * 2) obj = B() result = obj.add(3) print(result) What will be the output of the given code?

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below python code.def create_and_write_file(filename, num_lines): with open(filename, "w") as f: for i in range(1, num_lines + 1): f.write(f"Line {i}\n") def random_access_read(filename, seek_pos): with open(filename, "r") as f: first_chars = f.read(5) f.seek(seek_pos) line = f.readline() rest = f.readlines() for line in rest: print(line.strip()) def overwrite_some_text(filename, overwrite_pos, text): with open(filename, "r+") as f: f.seek(overwrite_pos) original = f.readline() f.seek(overwrite_pos) f.write(text + "\n") filename = "example_file.txt" num_lines = 6 seek_pos = 10 overwrite_pos = 21 overwrite_text = "OVERWRITTEN_TEXT" create_and_write_file(filename, num_lines) overwrite_some_text(filename, overwrite_pos, overwrite_text) Based on the given code snippet answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: Consider the below python code.def categorize_numbers(numbers): categories = { "cat_1": set(), "cat_2": set(), "cat_3": set() } def check(n): if n % 5 == 0: return True return False for num in numbers: if num % 2 == 0: categories["cat_1"].add(num) else: categories["cat_2"].add(num) if check(num): categories["cat_3"].add(num) return categories result = categorize_numbers([ 2, 3, 4, 2, 5, 6, 3, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10, 5, 4, 7, 8, 3, 10, 2 ]) Based on the given code snippet answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: Consider the below python code.def categorize_numbers(numbers): categories = { "cat_1": set(), "cat_2": set(), "cat_3": set() } def check(n): if n % 5 == 0: return True return False for num in numbers: if num % 2 == 0: categories["cat_1"].add(num) else: categories["cat_2"].add(num) if check(num): categories["cat_3"].add(num) return categories result = categorize_numbers([ 2, 3, 4, 2, 5, 6, 3, 2, 7, 8, 9, 10, 5, 4, 7, 8, 3, 10, 2 ]) Based on the given code snippet answer the given subquestions.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"Introduction to Python"** exam, along with **key equations/logic** (where applicable) and **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Python Basics & Syntax**
- **Truthiness in Python**:
  - `None`, `0`, `""` (empty string), `[]`, `{}`, `()` evaluate to `False` in boolean contexts.
  - All other values (non-zero numbers, non-empty sequences) evaluate to `True`.
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    if None: print("True")  # Never executes
    elif 0: print("True")   # Never executes
    else: print("False")    # Executes
    ```

- **Conditional Statements**:
  - `if-elif-else` ladder executes the **first true condition**.
  - **Key Logic**:
    ```python
    if <condition1>:
        <block1>
    elif <condition2>:
        <block2>
    else:
        <block3>
    ```

---

### **2. Data Structures**
#### **A. Tuples**
- **Immutable** (cannot be modified after creation).
- **Operations**:
  - Concatenation (`+`), slicing (`[start:end]`), membership (`in`).
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    t1 = (1, 2)
    t2 = (3, 4)
    t3 = t1 + t2  # (1, 2, 3, 4)
    t3[2:4]       # (3, 4)
    5 in t2       # False
    ```

#### **B. Lists**
- **Mutable** (can be modified).
- **Key Operations**:
  - Slicing (`lst[1:4] = [100]` replaces elements 1-3 with `[100]`).
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    lst = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]
    lst[1:4] = [100]  # lst becomes [0, 100, 4]
    ```

#### **C. Dictionaries**
- **Key-Value Pairs**:
  - Access/Modify: `d[key]`, `d[key] = value`.
  - Check existence: `key in d`.
  - **Nested Dictionaries**:
    ```python
    data = {"A": {"x": 10}, "B": {"y": 20}}
    data["A"]["x"] += 5  # Updates to 15
    ```

#### **D. Sets**
- **Unordered**, **unique** elements.
- **Operations**:
  - Union (`|`), intersection (`&`), difference (`-`).
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    cat1 = {2, 4, 6}
    cat3 = {5, 10}
    cat1 & cat3  # set() (no common elements)
    ```

---

### **3. Loops & Comprehensions**
#### **A. `for` Loops**
- Iterate over sequences (lists, tuples, strings, dictionaries).
- **Example**:
  ```python
  for i in range(3):  # 0, 1, 2
      print(i)
  ```

#### **B. List Comprehensions**
- **Syntax**: `[expression for item in iterable if condition]`.
- **Example** (2D matrix):
  ```python
  matrix = [[(i+1) + j*3 for i in range(3)] for j in range(3)]
  # Output: [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6], [7, 8, 9]]
  ```

#### **C. `enumerate`**
- Returns `(index, value)` pairs.
- **Example**:
  ```python
  for i, row in enumerate(array):
      total += row[i]  # Diagonal sum
  ```

---

### **4. Functions & Scope**
- **Default Arguments**:
  ```python
  def func(a, b=10):  # b defaults to 10
      return a + b
  ```
- **Recursion**:
  - Base case + recursive case.
  - **Example** (tree traversal):
    ```python
    def procedure(child_dict, i):
        if i not in child_dict:
            return 1
        ans = 1
        for j in child_dict[i]:
            ans += procedure(child_dict, j)
        return ans
    ```

---

### **5. File Handling**
- **Modes**:
  - `"w"` (write), `"r"` (read), `"r+"` (read/write).
- **Key Methods**:
  - `f.read(n)`: Reads `n` characters.
  - `f.readline()`: Reads one line.
  - `f.seek(offset)`: Moves file pointer to `offset`.
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    with open("file.txt", "w") as f:
        f.write("Hello\nWorld")
    with open("file.txt", "r") as f:
        print(f.read(5))  # "Hello"
    ```

---

### **6. Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)**
#### **A. Classes & Inheritance**
- **Inheritance**:
  - Child class inherits from parent (`class Child(Parent)`).
  - `super()` calls parent’s methods.
- **Method Overriding**:
  - Child can redefine parent’s methods.
- **Example**:
  ```python
  class Shape:
      def area(self):
          return "Not defined"
  class Rectangle(Shape):
      def area(self):
          return self.width * self.height
  ```

#### **B. Special Methods**
- `__init__`: Constructor.
- `__str__`: String representation.

---

### **7. Exception Handling**
- **`try-except` Blocks**:
  - Catch specific exceptions (`IndexError`, `KeyError`).
  - **Example**:
    ```python
    try:
        print(list[10])  # IndexError
    except IndexError:
        print("Error")
    except:
        print("Other error")
    ```

---

### **8. Algorithms & Logic**
#### **A. Recursive Tree Traversal**
- **Logic**:
  ```python
  def count_nodes(child_dict, i):
      if i not in child_dict:
          return 1
      ans = 1
      for j in child_dict[i]:
          ans += count_nodes(child_dict, j)
      return ans
  ```
- **Output**: Counts all nodes in a tree structure.

#### **B. Matrix Diagonal Sum**
- **Logic**:
  ```python
  total = 0
  for i in range(n):
      total += matrix[i][i]  # Diagonal elements
  ```

---

## **Key Equations/Logic**
| **Concept**               | **Equation/Logic**                          | **Example**                                  |
|---------------------------|--------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------|
| Truthiness                | `None`, `0`, `""` → `False`                | `if None: print("Never")`                    |
| Dictionary Update         | `d[key] += val` if key exists               | `my_dict["a"] += 2`                         |
| Tuple Slicing             | `t[start:end]`                             | `(1,2,3,4)[1:3] → (2,3)`                    |
| List Slicing Assignment   | `lst[1:4] = [100]`                         | `[0,1,2,3] → [0,100,3]`                      |
| Recursion (Tree Traversal) | `ans = 1 + sum(procedure(child_dict, j))`  | Counts nodes in a tree                      |
| File Pointer Movement     | `f.seek(offset)`                           | Moves to `offset`th byte                     |
| Set Operations            | `A & B` (intersection), `A | B` (union)   | `{2,4} & {4,6} → {4}`                       |
| Inheritance               | `super().__init__()`                       | Calls parent’s constructor                  |

---

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Python Data Structures] --> B[Tuples]
    A --> C[Lists]
    A --> D[Dictionaries]
    A --> E[Sets]

    B --> B1[Immutable]
    B --> B2[Concatenation: +]
    B --> B3[Slicing: [start:end]]

    C --> C1[Mutable]
    C --> C2[Slicing Assignment: lst[1:4] = [100]]
    C --> C3[Methods: append(), extend()]

    D --> D1[Key-Value Pairs]
    D --> D2[Nested Dictionaries]
    D --> D3[Methods: keys(), values()]

    E --> E1[Unordered, Unique]
    E --> E2[Operations: &, |, -]
```

```mermaid
graph TD

    G --> G1[Truthiness: None, 0, "" → False]
    G --> G2[First True Block Executes]

    H --> H1[Iterate Sequences]
    H --> H2[enumerate: Index-Value Pairs]

    I --> I1[Syntax: [x for x in iterable]]
    I --> I2[Matrix Generation]
```

```mermaid
graph TD
    J[OOP] --> K[Classes & Objects]
    J --> L[Inheritance]
    J --> M[Method Overriding]

    K --> K1[__init__: Constructor]
    K --> K2[__str__: String Representation]

    L --> L1[Parent-Child Relationship]
    L --> L2[super(): Call Parent Methods]

    N[File Handling] --> N1[Modes: w, r, r+]
    N --> N2[Methods: read(), seek(), write()]
    N --> N3[Context Managers: with open()]
```

```mermaid
graph TD
    O[Exception Handling] --> P[try-except Blocks]

    P --> P1[Catch Errors Gracefully]
    P --> P2[Multiple except Blocks]

    R[Recursion] --> R1[Base Case]
    R --> R2[Recursive Case]

```
